projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

div.p: ELEGIES Celebrating the Happy Memory OF Sr. HORATIO VEERE Baron of TILBURY, Collonell Generall of the English, In the Vnited Provinces, AND Mr. of the ORDNANCE in ENGLAND, &c.
LONDON, Printed by T. Badger, for Christopher Meredith, at the Crane in Pauls Church-yard. 1642.

To
The vertuous and most noble
LADIE,
The LADIE VEERE
late wife to the ever honored
the Lord HORATIO VEERE,
TO
Whose happy Memory be these Elegies
ERECTED,
AND HERE
Most humbly Dedicated to her Ladyship
In due Reverence to His Fame
and
GLORIE.

div.head: To the unfading Memory of the Lord HORATIO VEERE deceased.

lg.l: IF you would be resolv'd whose Dust lies here
Know 'tis the remnant of that Noble VEERE
Whose tall Atchivements fill so large a room,
As Europe is too narrovv for their Tombe,
And He can never perish in His Name
Whilst there is such a thing a broad as Fame.
Iust Belgia had cause enough to boast,
That He alone vvas her confiding Hoast;
Who singly vvhen the Army vvas avvay
Suppli'd the place of the Militia.
And had unto her Seventeen Provinces
E're this, united the Antipodes;
And future times vvill deem that Land to lie
Entrench'd in teares that fell vvhen He did dye,
And it vvill be Impiety to make
It firme, but rather drovvn it for His sake,
For the Low-Countries by His Deeds shall be
Preferr'd in Story to High-Germany.
But Thou hast so out-fought Thy selfe that time,
Will thinke such Actions could be none of Thine,
And vvhil'st Thou did'st Thy Vertue so advance,
'Twas not a Truth but a well fainde Romance,
And I, preserving of Thy Honour, feare
Thou vvilt be thought no Lord having no Peere.

div.head: TO THE MEMORY OF THAT NOBLE, WORTHY HORATIO the Lord VEERE, &c.

lg.l: YEt least the Dutch should steale his Fame, and so
Hereafter call him Van HORATIO,
I'le speake Him Englands Glory vvee'd not loose
His Name for the best Kingdom vve could choose
Here as in Sternehold's Verses, you shall meet
Stout Piety on lame uneven feet.
But hurts are Souldiers Graces, then 'tvvill be
No blemish if he take a vvound from me,
Though more perhaps in Old Coranto's se'd,
Which for his sake are studied and still read
Yet vvill I boldly vvrite, though nothing say;
He of rack'd Phancy too doth win the day.
First then be pleas'd to knovv (though Calo thought
The stoutest Souldiers from the Plough vvere brought)
That His descent vvas High, His bloud did spring
From the cleare Fount vvhere Arts have nourishing
Oxsord, like Janus Temple, novv shall be
For War as Peace, for Mars as Mercury,
'Tis Heresie to think brave Spirits bud
From Vulgar veines svveld up vvith Whey and Mud
Soft Beauties to beare Souldiers hence have povver
VEERE of a Lady's borne, Mars of a Flower.
But He high Births as things of chance did scorne
He liv'd more Nobly far than He vvas borne.
He left the Wanton Chambers, vvhere soft Beds
Beare Feathers and vvhat's lighter Courtiers heads:
And chose the Fields of Honor; they that have
The Earth their Bed, claime Heaven for their Grave,
Hard nights bred solid Fame, thus Jacob did
And's Pillovv straite became His Pyramid,
Thinking all City-businesse sloath, He vvent
(His life being a true Warfare) to a Tent,
Where He in sleeps and Holy-dayes, did more
Service, than others tugging the Oare.
He did not travell forth as others, vvho
Steale their ovvn Goods, yea their ovvn Bodies too;
And with their Heeles pay Debts in Germany
Not taking Armes, so much as Sanctuary
Who go to Sea to shun the City-Fleet.
And hoyse sayle only to avoyd the Sheet;
Thinking unlavvfull births, and Murders here,
May expiated be by killing there.
Nor vvas he by that old State-Policy sent
Thither, as to a noble Banishment,
Because His Active Soule so high did rise
That Conquering vvas all His Exercise
He vvent to practise there, for our defence,
Here He vvould use, not learn Experience.
Like Good Physitians, all at home being vvell
He strove exotique Poysons to expell
His shedding Bloud no Malice vvas, but skill;
'Tvvas one Act of His Charity, to kill,
No more Saint George for England, vve novv knovv
A Name of greater force, HORATIO.
Had you but seen Him all besmear'd vvith bloud
As if His Bodies inside, outward stood
Hovv He did boldly vvalke vvith sure steps, vvhen
The Earth was buried vvith unburied Men:
And had no more feare in His Face than One
That rides in Triumph vvhen the vvorld is Wonne.
Hovv he did march through Gore to th'Enemy
As if He vvent through Baths of Luxury.
To meet his Toyes, having no other light
But vvhat did sparkle from the svvord in fight;
And all this too for Strangers, vvhat could Hee
Have dar'd to set his Native Countrey free;
He that did thus for's Pleasure, would have done
Wonders indeed, had but his King look't on.
He that have fire to muskets there, for's ovvn
Realm, vvould have leap'd through Cannons to a Tovvn,
Should He have lead Army to a fight
The Sun again had stop'd to vievv the sight
More than Necessity, His Example had
Made Basenesse fierce, and Lethargy turn mad.
You that at Calis Sands vvill sooner fight
For the word Lye, or Whore than the Kings Right.
Who vvhen you go to Wars, take chiefest care
That yee be stor'd vvith povvder for your haire
That dresse your selves like those that Tempt and Wooe,
As if each Mars should be a Ʋeuus too.
And Ladies like black patches weare, no vvound
But vvhat came from the Curling-Iron there found
That complement, and out of modesty
Wo'nt dare to go to th' Front 'oth 'Enemy;
Wishing your Plumes made Wings, vvhen you should fight
Warring alone like Parthians by flight
Who if ye can fright children in the street,
And look avvay all Creditors ye meet
Stalke in the vapouring stride, vvearing Buffe Cloaths,
For vvhich you pay nothing but nevv coynd-Oaths,
Passe for try'd Captaines; knovv that Worthy VEERE
Could embrase dangers that you dare not heare:
Yet he nere fought for Mistrisse; 'Tvvas his care
To ranke his Souldiers rather than his hayre,
When he desired to read his vvounded face
That could check Tumults, his Svvord vvas his Glasse
His deeds, not vvords, did force the Peoples vvonder
Thus in the highest Region there's no thunder
He did not like Dull Mercuries only shevv
The vvay vvith's finger, but vvith His feet too,
And vvould have the first blovv, scorning to be
The chiefe in Place, and not in Drudgerie.
Yet did he never vveare Inchantments, like
Those that first put on Helmets, then bid strike.
'Tvvas He, and Truth, that could their Foes oppresse,
As Adam avve'd the Beasts vvith nakednesse.
He loath'd security, as much as Feare,
To give Wounds is lesse Glorious, than to beare
Lictors are valiant so, Lavvrels become
Their heads alone that suffer Martyrdome.
Though Age and Wounds had given him Writs of Ease,
Yet vvould he Halt, and Cravvle to th'Enemies,
And vvith lame Feete trample them dovvn, His hand
Made Myriads fall, then vvhen he could not stand.
Thus Weapons hack'd hurt more; and an old Wall
Conquers th'Invader even by its fall.
To speake him yet more Valiant, I must say
He vvas a Covvard, and vvould lose the Day,
When 'tvvas a sin to fight, Ill Victory
Being at the best but brave Iniquity.
'Tvvas the good Fight he fought, His Conscience
Not Fame, alone vvas His Intelligence,
He did not dravv to raise, but sheath up lars,
As 'tvvere the svvord of Iustice, not of Wars.
Nor vvas He rashly fierce at the Drums beat,
Who like the Sun had light vvith all his heat,
Though some mad Captaines think Religion,
A thing belonging only to the Govvn,
Langhing Devotion out o'th' Campe, and say
He's a dull foolish Covvard that does Pray,
Yet vvas He nere asham'd of Piety
Preferring that still before Victory.
Teares sav'd His Bloud, Faith did His Shield out last
His vvay to shun a famine vvas to fast.
Forts Altars vvere, Guns Censers, vvhence did rise
Incense, nor did He Kill, but Sacrifice.
His Svvord like that l'th' Doore of Paradice
Stood not to keep out Men alone, but Vice:
Each under His Command appear'd a Saint,
As if His Campe vvere the Church Militant,
Angels His Trumpets blew, so 't might be thought
The Spaniards Gyants like 'gainst Heaven fought,
No drinking matches there: Their Temperance such
They liv'd a sober life amongst the Dutch
They knevv't strong vveaknesse only, to beat back
The Spaniards Horse, and yeeld unto their Sack
Others may boast their care in that they knovv
Their Souldiers Names, He knevv their Nature too:
And in each Rank most busie did appeare,
He like the God of War vvas every vvhere
Compare some Routs, to his society,
Their Men vvant his Horses humanity.
While other Armies Thefts and Rapes professe,
Not robbing Cloaths alone, but Nakednesse.
Whose Pensions the High Way; and th' Neighbours be
Vex'd vvith their Guard, as much as Enemie.
His vvas all Honesty; The Countrey-Men
Lost not their Cock (though Mars his bird) nor Hen,
Vertues alone vvere there begot, they'd be
Fathers of Countries, not of Progeny.
Thus Jonas like he liv'd i'th' Iavves of Death
Oft dravving vvith his Ovvn, a Cannons breath
Yet nothing had or Will, or Povver to cease
On Him, but that Great Blessing length of dayes
He, vvhom the Wars prefer'd in Peace did dye
Thus, thus to Fall, vvas a great Victory.
'Las 'tis no Wonder if our Cities Majors
Heape to their Treasury some silver Haires,
They like lean Oxen scarce deserve the Knife,
Who is't that envies Flies alonger Life!
Tis nothing to scape drowning on the shore;
But vvhen that Man doth hive, vvhose body bore
More Shafts than Sceva, or the Porcupine;
Whose thing vvas the Earths Vrne, and's Brest a mine
Of Lead, vve straight conclude that His Defence
Was the sole Hot and Svveat of Providence,
If maym'd and Aged Oakes are sacred, vvell
May vve maintaine, in Him a God did dvvell.
What but Divinity could so rule the Dart
That it should strike each Member, but the Heart.
His Foes (as Satan Job's) could's Body make
One perfect Sore, His Life they could not take.
But all these Praises are to scant and poore,
The malice of His Foes must needs say more
Armies of Statues build, for every stone
Other Graves have, exect a stately Tovvn
Instead of Alabaster Boys, ranke here
A Troop of Horse, a band of Foot-men there.
Then heape up Svvords and Bucklers, till vve see
His Monument, our greatest Armorie
After all this, 'tvvill be too meane a roome,
He more deserves a Temple than a Tombe.

div.head: On the death of the honourable HORATIO VEERE Baron, of Tylbury, &c.

lg.l: HOvv have you, wrong'd our VEERE to let Him lye,
So long interr'd vvithout an Elegie!
For though the choycest Artists you may use,
His Tombe is but halfe cut that vvants a Muse.
Belgia can vvitnesse, if she e're did beare,
So stay'd a Guide, so fierce a Souldier;
His fury like a God He did dispence,
And every blovv turn'd to a pestilence.
Yet vvith such skill His Conquests vvould foretell
That He convinc't and prov'd each miracle,
Thus as th' old Chaldees vvaiting on the Sun
From East to West, vvhen first his course begun,
And vvhen it fell, knevv hovv remote soe're
Strange Lands and Men, because the day vvas there:
So vvhere this mighty Planet cast his eye,
The Tovvn vvas then but a Discovery:
And should a generall feare the States benum
His influence had strength to overcom.
Nor did He one yeares Prodigy appeare,
But grevv a Star, and fil'd that Hemispeare;
His life vvas a full History of War,
And every Act a Worthie's Character.
None could His dayes by Months, or Seasons frame,
Dangers vvere all His Spring, His Harvest Fame.
Attend a greater Wonder! bring me one
An Hero too in His Religion:
One so devout, that vvhen His just decree
Beates dovvn the Foe, an Angell strickes not Hee:
One so precise and valiant, vve may svveare
The Leader Priest, then vvill I call him VEERE.

div.head: A Dialogue betvvixt ALEXIS and DAMON, on the death of the Lord VEERE.

sp.speaker: ALE.
sp.l: Farevvell to all my Flocks, farevvell to all,
One sad farevvell to my deare Cloes call,
And then I've done. Da. Fie young Alexis, fie!
'Tis not they love, but feare thou hast to dye
That thus detaines thee, see yo'nde troupe of Svvaines
Are mustered up from out the Neighbouring plaines,
Our great God Pan has said it, 'tis decreed
Each jolly Lad shall break his Pipe and reed;
There's in exchange a better musicke found
The noyse o'th' Drum, and the shirll Trumpets sound:
Each one must quit his wonted Shephcadrs Gray,
And clad in Iron now fetch in the May.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I've done, But who is he that now must guide
Our hands, to whom swords yet have been deny'd.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: Great Pan takes care of that: 'Tis he that can,
Give strength and Art to the unpractis'd Man.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: But Father, I have heard you lately tell,
Of Wars that in your younger time befell,
Had we but him that did in them Command,
We'd dare against the sturdiest Foe to stand.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: The great Lord VEERE thou meanst? Al. I, sure that's He
Me thinks the Name it selfe doth testifie.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: It does indeed my Son, It is a Name
That needs no Verse to 'advance or crown His Fame,
And only lesse than he Himselfe it stands
I'th'Campe with Mars, and equally Commands.
This Man its worthy'st Master did inherit
A soule beyond the greatest Roman spirit.
O, I could tell you Wonders! This was He
Whose very looke commanded Victory:
My selfe have seen Him midst the Foes to stand
Cutting what threads he pleas'd with his own hand.
Not unlike Fate it selfe, whiles every blow
Provok'd, and overcame the stoutest Foe.
But this He did a Youth; when He was grown
To perfect man, He scarce could seeme to owne
Such deeds as these: That which He did before,
Was well, but then He doubled it, and more.
That heat which warm'd His Arme before, and bred
Such wonders there, was Active too in's head,
Which made Him strong, and able to subdue
Not Men alone, but their affections too.
Thus a continuall Conqueror He stood,
Not only stout, but resolutely good,
And to Himselfe being fixt, and constant still,
He was not mov'd, although besieg'd with Ill;
But He alas is long since dead, and we
Have nothing left us but His Memory
To honour which, this short time I've to live
In spight of my gray haires, I'le freely give.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: And I, if that these broyles I do survive
In prayse of Him, will yearly Feasts contrive:
But if (deny'd by the Fates) I chance to fall,
I'le order't so, that my deare Cloe shall.

div.head: These consecrated to the perpetuall Memory of Sir HORATIO VEERE, Generall of the English, Baron of Tilbury, &c.

lg.l: CAnnot the Drum toule, and ring out? The Bell
Is a too peacefull sound to speake His Knell;
To weep were a disparagement: This Vrne
Expects that you should rage, rather than mourne
Those Obsequies befit a Souldier, That
Storme, not bewaile, that rave, not pine at Fate:
Yet had our Worthy HEROE perish'd in
The Canons fury, I had patient bin,
And only tore my hayre, or groan'd; but thus
To see Him drop away like one of us,
Alderman like dissolv'd into His Dust,
Whoever is not frantick, is not Iust.
Is it this then our City Tribes call Peace
That forbids Guns, and Slaughters with Disease?
Whose sole Innocence is that it destroyes
Vnheard, and can massacre vvithout noyse?
Thus vvhilst Syrenes glitter like Sun-shine, they
Accept a lasting flash for a faire day:
Avvay vvith this counterfeit Calme, I see
There is no peace but Immortality:
The same houre feasts and kils, vvho can beware
Of such as smile and murther us? Wel-fare
Plaine-dealing fire, and sword, that vvhen they stay
Demand a life, and not thus steale't avvay;
Yet War hath this Art too; thus the stout Wall
That out-brav'd Cannons, by a Mine doth fall.
Here lyes a loyall Souldier, vvho vvas 'ere
Disloyall, or no Souldier, vvas no VEERE.
No VEERE yet ever durst thinke it a right
And just plea to Rebell, cause He durst fight:
Would vve all vvere this Family: there's fevv
That dare so much, and dare so little too.
Here lyes a devout Souldier, Yet n'ere one
That mutined to prove's Religion:
Nor vvas He of that Crevv, vvhose Captaine-ships
Conust in a big voyce, and bristled lips.
That thumpe the board, and roare out Oaths so large
You'd think they did not discourse, but discharge?
That damne, and rashly tilt at every breast
They Ken, these are not valiant, but possest.
The best of His Artillery vvas prayer,
Nor did He kill, but vvhere 'tvvas sin to spare.
Hovv oft vve do divine? Thus Seers of old
(They say) could seldom their ovvn Savves unfold:
'Tis no hard matter to prognosticate,
We can fore-tell too, not understand Fate.
They vvho this day desir'd VEERE'S Company
Did not so much invite, as Prophesy;
The Cates vvere not a Feast, but Type, and vvill'd
Not to be fed on, but to be fulfill'd.
Such plenty fitly shaddovved forth the store
Of that blest place, vvhere He n'ere hungers more.
But sure vve do mistake, nor is He gone
To His rest, but on an Expedition,
Yo'n place of peace, Heaven also hath its Wars,
And VEERE is chosen Generall of those Stars
That must in order 'gainst some Sisera fight
And put some Beliall multitude to flight,
We much mistearm'd our late unhappinesse
The Plague; it vvas no pestilence but a presse:
Our people dyed not, but march't hence, and are
The present forces of this Holy War,
Legions that serve under our VEER: let none
Miscall that then His funerall Scutchion
Which is His Banner; nor y'on Momument
His Tombe (ominous syllable) 'tis His Tent:

div.head: On the ever Honored Generall, Sir HORATIO VEERE, Baron of Tylbury, &c.

lg.l: HORATIO VEERE, that vvas the name strock death
Into a Palsey, toyl'd Him out of breath!
When but pronounc't, bals vvith sulphureous fires
Wing'd and vvith musick from His martiall quires
Sent of, conveyed HORATIO VEERE
Aloud, but stroke the hearer dead vvith feare;
His was a pious Valour, He could pray
And sight, not for His Life, but for the day.
It vvas His glory that the Sun should fall
With His opposers, and their funerall
Be mourn'd by night alone, and vvhen that Lampe
Did rise and shine again, that from His Campe
He might behold the recking of their Gore
Exhale, and like thick clouds of bloud hang o're
Their broaken Regiments, portending nought
But ruine as gainst Heaven they had fought.
Live Newport in His fame, and may thy Tovvers
Flourish the Trophees of His svvord and povvers.
They vvon thee hardly, for when almost spent,
HORATIO hop't no other monument
To raise His Memory • nto the World,
Then slaughtered Piles of His ovvn forces, hurld
By th'accidentall reele of War, rebounds
Like lightening on His Foe, and deeper vvounds.
And novv the day is VEERE's, for in the field
Death durst not meet Him, cause 'a vvould not yeeld.
But the grim Traytor fees a poore disease,
That it selfe shooke with feare t'approach, or cease
So high a Spirit, to conspire with Age
And vvearied Nature, how to cleare the Stage
Of this Tragedian; He whose arme hath movv'd
More than the pale mans sythe, is now bestovv'd
'Mongst the insulting vvormes, vvith His flesh feed
They'l justly sympathize, and 'gainst the tread
Shall crush them, turn again, as they should say
We are VEERE's wormes, there's Valour in His Clay.

div.head: Vpon the Death of the Honourable and most Heroick Sir HORATIO VEERE, Baron of Tilhury, Generall of the English Regiments in the Vnited Provinces, &c.

lg.l: THough at thy Name Great VEERE, even Poets fight,
And Act those battles, they first meant to write;
Dare talke of Guns vvithout an Agnes fit,
Make svvords the scope, and sharpnesse of their Wit;
Beleager all their Muses, and not tell
But muster up thy vvhole Acts Chronicle;
Do all in Tearmes of War; So that vve meet
Tovvns sackt, and Cities taken in one sheet;
All these are but Griefes Policy, to shevv
Thy Death can make their sorrovvs valiant too:
And being th'are so, a part of Thee expresse,
Who e're is like thee, seems to vvant Thee lesse:
But vvho is left to be so! is there novv
A conquering Name that may succeed as Thou
Didst thy fam'd Brother! (nay vve'l give Him more)
That may excell; as thou didst Him before:
For where such spirits meet that All are best
Tis equall Glory to be thought the least.
Yet He must be a Man vvhose budding Fame
Can fright an Army, vvhose halfe-spoken Name
Beats dovvn vvhole Tovvns and Bulvvarks: hath been heard
Lovvder than Cannon-shot, and surer fear'd:
One that's made up by Transmigration,
Of more than the Nine-Worthies into One
And beares a Troope of soules; that vve may say,
Himselfe's an Army, though His Men b'avvay;
When more than this is added, bring That He
Which hath more Yet, or else he's lesse than Thee:
And why all These? 'tvvill be enough to be
Lesse than the least to knovv he's short of Thee;
Let him be first a VEERE; his Armies All;
As vvell their Spirit, as their Generall:
Infuse them vvith his ovvn true Valour, and
Teach't by Example; Act his ovvn Command;
Let his ovvn Name the vvhole Corantoes fill,
And make them be tvvice printed, let it still
Come fresh into Paules walkes, to them vvhich doo
Digest each meale vvith Nevves, be somes, meale too:
Have such a soule from vvhich vve'd easily take
Troops of Commanders; each stout look to make
A Captaine; vvhat brave vvord soever fell
Out of his mouth create a Colonell
When all these heapes of Valour do agree,
To forme one Man again, That Man is Thee.
But let him dye like Thee too, Fate begun
His envy long before; Thy Death alone.
Styl'd him full Victor: 'tvvas some Craft to have
Part of Thy body in a Living Grave;
To make Thee feele th'increase of death; and be
Thy selfe a Part in Thine ovvn Tragoedy:
Witnesse that Earth to Earth vvhich in Thy Thigh
Forc'd by a Bullet buried there did lye;
And Thou didst Live a Corpse, not to be kill'd
At last by Thy loose Palscy, but Full-fill'd;
Like some Great Prophesie, vvhose End comes slovv
And sure, though 'twas begun the Age agoe:
We Challenge Thy first death: this vvas too lovv
An Home disease for Thy Great Overthrovv;
Even feeble in it selfe, far from the Povver
Of being such a Victors Conquerour,
And might in some vveake Alderman have been
A serious thought, the Nods good Iudgement seeme:
'Tis flat against our Faith to thinke Thy bold
And vigorous breast could ever suffer Cold,
Or any shaking; no not even the fall
Of a Town Vndermin'd, or Blovvn up Wall
When th'Earth and Ayre affrighted in those parts
Suffer one Palsey vvith the Tovvnsmens hearts.
Yet since this is Thy Period, and in Thee
Two Nations Valours at once shaken bee
The States and Englands; Yet our Fates are crosse
Since vve may Boast, vvhen they shall feele Thy losse.

div.head: An Elegy on the Dead of Sir HORATIO VEERE, Lord Baron of Tilbury, Mr of the Ordnance in England, and Generall o're the English forces in the Vnited Provinces.

lg.l: HAd not the Triumphs that attended Thee
When death proclaim'd Thy Immortality,
Borne vvitnesse of Thy Fate, I should ha' thought
Thy Enemies in policy had wrought
A fiction for Thy Death, for that alone
(They knew) could vvorke their Foes confusion:
Who then must fall to ruine, vvhen at once
They lost in Thee the strength of every Sconce.
Thou vvert all Frontiers to the States, and vvee
Did yeeld them Brill and Flushing sending Thee.
So dread full vvas great VEERE, so loud His Fame,
That absent, they might conquer by His Name.
He gave them rich Excise, his spoyles brought in,
Pay for the nevv designe of the next Spring;
Prevented all their Taxes, that their doubt
And Counsell vvholy vvas vvhere to lay out.
Which Tovvn, vvhat City next should feele and beare
The vvealth o'th' last, and be its Sepulcher.
Hovv could he choose but conquer, vvhen that He
Mixt vvith His povvder, Incense, Piety
Gave fire; His Hoast vvas cleane, and vvhose're
Did sound His Trumpe, vvas first an Angell rhere.
'S Example purg'd the Campe, His Troops that durst
Subdue the Cloysters, durst live purer first:
You that succeed and vvould 'ore come like Him,
Religion Learn, this vvas VEERE's stratagem.

div.head: TO THE MEMORY OF the Right Honourable HORATIO VEERE, Baron of Tilbury.

lg.l: THis distance does become us, who can write
A lyne worthy great VEERE, although he might
Have Ages graunted? they on whose slighted hearse
Some Poet hyr'd quickly howles out a verse
Dye with their Elegies; An Age we see
Is almost gon, more than the memory
Of others Pasts, ere we dare venter forth
To celebrate His full and perfect worth.
So let's go on still: Let not our zeale out-scan
Due Reverence, first Adoration done
To His blest Ashes; kissing the cold earth thrice,
And thrice three times the Marble, with advice
Pronounce we great HORATIO, not as we do,
Some petty Hero, with a sigh or two,
But as we do the Thunderer: we now
Sing not an Elegy, but pay a vow
In a Commemorative Sacrifice
To Him long since amongst the Dieties.
Nor do we here our wits and fancies try,
'Tis a devout and holy Extafy.
We offer Hymnes, such as in dayes of old
Religious Matrons, and Chast Virgins told
In pious numbers of great Hectors fame,
Of Jove, of Mars, and of Alcides name:
So sing we His, but with a zeale as far
Beyond those cold ones, as he the God of War,
Or greater Jove exceld, whose very look,
Vanquisht his foes, as if by Thunder strook.
Thay can best tell His Acts, had we but been
Amidst their Troops, and felt as well as well as seen
Those vigorous Armes, that breast, those eyes of fire,
And at each frown our selves ready t'expire,
Feare would have made us Poets, and each fright
In bloud would His Fame and our Dirges writ:
We should have sworn Him an united band
And all the Gods muster'd up in His hand.
Yet Conquest puft Him not, nor did the flood
Which His Arme spilt, make Him delight in blood,
He was all peace, the tender harted mayd,
And Ages Syre whom Wars name makes afrayd,
Are not more milde, had His devotion been
Crown'd with a Miter, in a Surplice seen,
He had been Sainted; He to th' Church would be
Epitoniz'd Primitive Sanctity.
If by an Hierogliphick 'twere exprest,
Religion should be in His Picture drest.
No Hermit whom his zeale transformeth soe
That to the Altars Marble fixt He grow,
Is holyer, By Him a Regiment
Turnes to a Quire, a Church what was a Tent.
Preachers in Armes, and this He learnes from thence
To Heaven too, to offer violence.
Talke not of Him who Iust, Great, Holy writes
To severall men divided pethites,
Hector was valiant, Ʋlisses wise,
And Numa first Religion did divise.
These all lackt some thing of Perfection,
Something was still behind, who knowes but one,
And still Learne is a Child; who all things can

l.hi: In full perfection only is a Man.

div.head: On the death of Sir HORATIO VEERE, the right Valiant and brave Commander Lord Baron of Tylbury, &c.

lg.l: THy Name (great VEERE) can valour now inspire,
Which once did feare infuse, and raise us higher;
Incite our thoughts, not able to declare
Thy Merits ample, as their Actions were.
Religion was thy Banner, Faith thy Shield
Thou taught'st couragious Piety to weild
A Conquerors sword, thy Tents seem'd all to be
Made Sanctuaries with thy Purity.
Thy lamenesse was the strength of weaker States,
This thy Foes heard as Master of their Fates,
Which thou rul'st at thy will, Joves great decree
Thy sword, did act their truest Destiny.
Lame VEERE forsook not War, but rather us'd
Than His Commanders staffe, and only chus'd
His Muskets rest, armes VEERE'S weaknesse sought, He
Only seem'd lame, because he could not fly.
The Romish bastard Eagles durst not eye,
This glorious Sun Spaine seemed but to try
His valarous soule that she to th'World might boast
She VEERE withstood, and proud. because the lost
Romans themselves weare titles from that place,
Which they had spoyl'd, but VEERE hath greater grace
Cities assume from Him a noble Name,
And being sack't a greater glory claime.
Fate durst not once assault This Hero arm'd,
Her powerfull hand, the feare of's strength had charm'd
Death, justly now look's pale, amaz'd to see
Her selfe o're sway'd by His Mortality.
No strength against this Foe she knew prevail'd,
Therefore with policy she Him assailed,
Whilst on His quiet Couch at rest He lay,
At unawarres she forc't His soule away.
No Foc can boast VEERE'S death by fatall power
Alone subdu'de, He dyed a Conqueror.

div.head: On the Death of the Honourable Sir HORATIO VEERE, Baron of Tilbury.

lg.l: OVr eyes submit Teares like thy Captives bow,
Thy force o'recame before, Thy ruine now:
Thus old expiring Oakes crush and Create
Fame from their fall, and Triumphs from their Fate:
The courage was not Choler heere, the flame
Not from Complexion, but from Vertue came.
Valour's not borne of Nature, but the will,
They only conquer that with Iudgement kill.
The fire subdues the Ayre, yet his proud Rayes
Still without Trophies win still without bayes.
The Mind, not the tough flesh was His defence,
He lost the feare of wounds, but not the Sense,
That were t'have been some Engine and a stroak
Had prov'd Him a burst Iaveline, or sword broak;
His scarrs had then been Cracks, and every blow
Had hurt the Weapon, Statues conquer so.
No such resistance heere, the veines were known
Noble, and cleare as Saphires, yet not stone.
The Wars were not His plot, He did not eat
By the sword and wounds, and skirmish for His meat.
He could be stout in peace, and the same Ray
Threw lightning in the field, in the Court day.
Eagles are Eagles though no Foe appeare,
Good perfumes, though unchaf'd sweet Incense reare.
No Conquest made Him swell, an equall brow
Sustain'd the Lawrell, and the Cypresse bough:
The same Calme view'd Retreates and Victories;
One compos'd sense heard shoutes, and Elegies.
Weake spirits count their going back a doome,
And if they but retire, are straight o'recome.
Those Iewels cast a faint and drowsy light,
Which 'cause they are once sullied, are lesse bright:
The current stopt grew greater here, and He,
That did retyre a streame, return'd a Sea.
No rudenesse made the publick shares more thin,
Spoiles were His purchase only, ne're His sin,
Norich Foe made Him glad, no needy pause,
He fought not 'gainst the booty, but the cause:
He punisht Cities, pass'd no Village by,
The just heat scorcht the Phoenix with the Fly.
And having now subdude the Spamsh pride,
He saw no Foe could kill Him, and so dy'd.

div.head: On the Death of the right Valiant Sir HORATIO VEERE, Baron of Tilbury.

lg.l: AWay ye prouder Cowards that recite
Your stem from Ancestors, but not your Right,
And do as sure not merit th'Armes You beare,
As if Cowardise part of Gentry were;
Here' • one that by His Valour shew'd His Crest,
And with His sword blazon'd His Armes I'th' breast
Of's Enemies; And whosoever came
Opposer to Him, 's made Trophv to His Name.
Spaines forces I disprayse not, 'twas no shame,
That He your greater number over came:
Himselfe an Army was, in Ostends right
They fought 'gainst ods, that against Him did fight
What cruell Law of Nature is't? that thus
Condemnes to perils the Couragious?
That fortitude we no where find, unlesse
We find it be in danger and distresse.
We hazard still our nob lest minds, and all
We can is t'adorne Vertues funerall.
He now lives short that's good: our vertues sure
Are Blasing-stars or Commets, that endure
But their own ruine to foretell, and be
To'us Wonder, to themselves a Prodigy:
Nor must I here leave off it were a Lye
To name His Valour and not's Piety.
They still conjoyned were, there you might see
Vertue from any foule repulse was free.
It is no Solaecisme now to call
A Souldier Pious, nor is't now at all
Vntrue, it may be credible to say
'Twas not the Souldiers Liquor won the day;
Even in the Wars He was a Magistrate.
And did proportion to th' offence, the Fate;
• th' field us'd such authority; They were
VEERE's Subjects, All that did rebell 'gainst VEERE,
Religion's Enemies, were His, and who
Did 'gainst Him fight, did 'gainst Religion too.
He drew against her Enemies, and then
Did with His sword correct their vicious pen.
Not Mars's now, Fame's Trumpet sounds our VEERE
'Twas He that made the Church triumphant here.

div.head: On the Puissant and Gallant Commander the Lord HORATIO VEERE, Generall of the English in the Vnited Provinces.

lg.l: LOoke to Thy selfe Renowned VEERE, for though
'Tis said th'art sick o'th'Palsey, I say, No:
Safely collecting when I trembling see
'Tis not so much disease, as Enemy.
Who in so soft and silent pace did steale
Vpon health's Fort, escap'd all Centinell:
He? That's a single one when our VEERE's Ghost
Cannot be dispossess'd but by an Host.
Mischiefes must band, and still dispaire of Him
Vntill they fly to secret Stratagem.
So His Heroique Spirit might be o're seene,
To prove Him Man; o'recome had never been:
VEERE? Even the Name such heat and prowesse shewes
It ceases to be That and Title growes.
And yet what e're the piercingst Iudgment can
Find in the Name, was tripled in the Man.
Sounds it Religion, God, or Goodnesse? He
Was then the Priest, and that the Mystery,
Whose knee before that God and Heaven, sincere
Devotion dayly bent, but never Feare,
That servile sensuall passion, His free soule
Had cleare dismils'd, but did it's Name enroule
Amongst His vertues, as Schoole Divines do
With Hope, giving that a Names-sake virtue too.
So far between Himselfe and Heaven, but now
Shall we enquire after His valour, how
It sprung, grew up, spread through the World, I call
The same to witnesse it, charging That All
To bring true vidence in, then to review
Her ancient Records, and observe where true,
Nobly-descended, Loyall, Puissant, Deare
To all that's Good, the substantive was VEERE;
At the have mention of which Name you have
Heard eve'n th' unletter'd Peasant strait add brave,
Whose minds being too base't be Perill-proofe,
By reckoning Him, think the Land safe enough:
To which I had inclin'd, had not I known
He bore His Foe about Him, and did own
That treacherous Flesh, which vow'd He death should see
Though Himselfe maym'd, though Himselfe wounded be.
Oh! that That Vow was kept! Have I not seen
The troubled Fountaine cleare it selfe again,
Weeping the filth out with a kind of shame,
And blushing till her pristine silver came?
So should thy purer bloud rise up, boyle on,
And in disdaine work out the Infection.
Dicta • y can all Shaft, or Speare expell,
Why not thy soule (a nobler forme) as well?
Why not invulnerable, why not all,
The Priviledges Truth or Fable call?
Deserv'd He not so much, who was these three
Valour, Religion and Nobility.
Not in the vulgar manner, this in the Court
That in the Chamber, th'other in the Fort,
But all in each, so we now mourne His losse
Who 't once hath fought for the Colours and the Crosse.
Who with His Arme and sword, as not content
With th' bare Nobility of His descent,
Would purchace new, (when as our Monsieurs gilt
First are the Gentlemen, then weare the Hilt.)
Therefore Let's weep, if not till we are drown'd,
Yet let our pious Deluge wash His wound.
So layd I'th' Grave, weep still, for since VEERE's dead,
He's more than valiant can be comforted.

div.head: An Elegy to the Memory of Sir HORATIO VEERE, Baron of Tilbury.

lg.l: AFter this long amazement, This halfe death
The much astonish't World recovers breath
To utter her just plaints, which that great Crosse
Depress'd in silence; Now she feeles her losse
As rifing from a Traunce; Besotting griefe
Somewhat remitted, grant's us this reliefe
To manifest our sorrows, sighs burst forth
Now in articulate Nambers: whilst VEERE's worth
Inspires and Creates Poets, we dare try
Griefe dictating, to sob an Elegy.
He is an ample subject: His defects
Deserve to be admir'd: Who but reflects
Vpon His daring Lamenesse, may behold
Perfection imitable, He well could
Limpe into Honors bosome, vvhen ith' field
He vvore His Conquering svvord, untaught to yeeld,
He seem'd a Mars incarnate, vvith each looke
He vvounded His Majestick presence strook
Avve and amazement: As the timerous Deere
Flyes the pursuer, borrovving vvings of Feare,
So did the Spaniard his assaults: VEERE's Name
Epitomiz'd Artillery, His Fame
Was Engin, Cannon, and what e're doth win
Submission, and obedience. Yet in
The Court He could depose His frovvnes, and rayse
Such svveet yet sound discourse, merit such prayse
For solid judgement and advice as 'fH' had
Courted no Pallas, but of Arts. He made
Valour grovv courteous: No antipathy
Was found 'tvvixt Souldier and Civility:
In Him both vvere united. He well knevv
To vanquish in the Schooles, the practis'd Crevv,
And gaine Apollo's Lawrell. No lesse Charme
Was in His Tongue, then in His povverfull Arme:
All War to Him vvas Conquest, vvith that Art
He us'd His subtle Arguments to Dart,
With vvhich He threw His Iavelins, for no skill
His opposition could out vye, or quell:
This Living Science, only Ignorant,
What sin, vvhat a Tormented Conscience meant.
No vvonder if His Soule mounted on high,
Who could enthrone the humble dust i'th' skye?
VEERE's Center vvas the Pole: None ere deny'd
A Pure Intelligence a Heaven to Guide.

div.head: Vpon the death of Sir HORATIO VEERE, Late Generall of the English in the Low Countries, Baron of Tylbury.

lg.l: GIve me a sword dipt i'th' last Armies Bloud,
That He o're came Himselfe, though scarce with stood.
Quils are too childish: Rimers of our Age
Will allow Inke to Chamber-maid and Page.
Horrour becomes thee best, I would faigne writ
In the same Colour VEERE, as Thou did'st fight
Thou should'st have Poems, like thy Obsequy,
Such as doth valour shew even to see:
The Poet that can fully sing Thy prayse,
Deserves a Captaines place, instead of Bayes.
Thou that could'st sacke a Town with lookes, whose eyes
Like to two flames consum'd Thy Enemies;
Thy Souldiers were but witnesses, for feare
None should believe Thy Acts, if none were there.
Death Time did measure; when there gasping lay
Halfe a great Army, then 'twas thought mid-day.
Thy Troops mistrusted always Thou would'st dye
By Conquering, drowned in Thy Victory.
When thou could'st graspe a sword first, this was done
When nothing but by force and Armes was wonne.
But when 'twas prov'd to all that Thou could'st do
More than five Kingdomes durst to undergo,
Wounds then were envyed, 'twas felicity,
And Triumph judg'd to owe their death to thee.
Thy Lawrels were with so much ease obtain'd,
Thou blush'd as at the Garlands in Masks gain'd.
They spoyl'd thy Recreation, quickly all
N'ere yeelding sport enough, would fly, or fall;
'Twas but to take the Ayre for thee to win,
As if in thy own Lordship Thou hadst been
A Hawking, it was but to beate and then,
There rose, and straight way fled Coneys of men.
Armes were at last supersluous, as in peace:
Men in the fields did go for choyce of ease.
Thy Souldiers did but Traine, as we see Those
That go to Finsbu • y in their best Cloaths.
N •… was Thy conquest only in the Field
B • fore Thy Foes, Thou mad'st Thy selfe to yeeld.
For though so great in Birth, yet Thou could'st say,
Thou had'st seen Tragedies, and yet no Play:
Th • u did'st not look upon Thy curious bilt,
And doubt'st to draw Thy sword to spoyle the guilt;
Ev'n out of Hide-Parke, Thou durst fight, could'st make
Men fly, not only for thy Ladies sake.
Durst to appeare in Armes, not mov'd with Love,
Where th' Eusigne was, nor Ribbond nor a Glove.
Nor wast Thou sent beyond sea with intent
〈◊〉 , like Wine, Thy Lees to purge and vent:
Not was't a younger Brothers angry fire
Hating thy Country, rays'd Thy valour higher
Or feare of being ask't blessing in the street:
Or living a dull Captive in the Fleet.
No, no, Thy vertues counterpoys'd Thy bloud,
As Thou wert great and Noble, Thou wert good:
Thou wer't so al Compleat, Thy purer veyne
Of Goodnesse, not the very Campe could steyne.
Witnesse Thy zeale return'd: Men doubt so far
Whether Thou Leader wert in Church or War.
Not like those Cut-throats, who professe to kill,
That do come home from Sea, alike to spill
Blood here; who practice all the Might
On Drawers heads least They forget to fight;
That go in debt like hangmen, promise pay,
The next sedition, or next happy fray:
Who do lay seidge to Widdows, not to Towns,
Encounter with black-bags, and silken gowns:
Rest then brave spirit Thy great Name shall be,
Now our Commanding Leader stead of Thee.
Our hilts no more shall boast our Mistresse face
We'l have thy picture cut into that place.
Thy Tombe shall be our Altar, vve vvill trust
Lesse to our Castles povvder, than Thy Dust.

div.head: An Elegy on the right Honorable Sir HORATIO VEERE, Baron of Tilbury, late Generall of the English in the Vnited Provinces.

lg.l: SHould vve the Spaniards ruin'd Forces aske,
They'l tell us VEERE is dead, joyfull to maske
Thy vvorth i'th vvinding sheete, and novv first dare
To pry into Thy Greatnesse, vievv and square,
Thy Actions, vvhen they are sure Th'art dead,
On th' Name vvhich once vvas Thunder boldly tread,
Sure He vvas Warlike that alive could boast
More Terror, than His Gastly Corpes or Ghost.
Others strong bodies, Poets dare to call
The Armies Rampire, or a living Wall.
His eye vvas more like Wild-fire't could Command
Death surer than another's Pike or hand:
And yet hovv pious vvas He, you might say
He fought still for the Altars, and did svvay
Iustice's ovvn sword, His ardency in War
Was zealous heat, not fury, every Scar
Put him in mind o'th' Passion; Drum and Flute
Were never heard to make the Organs mute.
Lamenesse suppress'd Thee not, vvhen thou vvith Grace
Went'st on unequall legs a vvav'ring pace:
Thou seemd'st above thy selfe, and yet beneath
Thy Vertues, vvhich could tyre fames longest breath:
Wound's set Thee upright, He that dares be Lame
Or halt by th'svvord, knovves hovv to leane on Fame.

div.head: To the happy memory of Sir HORATIO VEERE, Baron of Tilbury, &c.

lg.l: YOu that have povverfull skill to cheate the Eye
With cunning Shaddows, and faire Imagerye
That can infuse into your rare designes
A seeming Life, by vvell proportioned Lines;
And give such Motion too, that vve admire
Your Pencill equall vvith Prometheus fire,
Ioyne Phansies, and conspire in every Part,
To make a generall Master-piece of Art.
Paint me a Mars, his Fauchion in his Hand,
In his Brow Valou, in his Eye Command;
Throughout his Face a sterne strong Beauty such
As can endure the Sun beames scorching touch,
Or Winters keener Breath, than chose the Strength
Of close compacted Limbs, rather than Length:
Let Him be mounted on a Fiery Steed
Of fiercest Courage, and the choycest Breed,
Proud of his Riders managing, from vvhence
He seemes inspir'd vvith Mind, as vvell as Sense.
For your By-Drought pitch me a Battle fought,
And all-most to a certaine Issure brought
Where to retreat vvere Ʋalour, and to be
The Conquer'd vvas a kind of Ʋictory
Dravv some pursuing, others flying: Heere
Let Divers stand hurt not 'vvth Shot, but Feare,
There Youngsters proud of easy Wounds, vvhose Skars
More than their Service shevv they've been 'nth' Wars,
And there an upstart Lord, vvho came to th' field
To make that Scutchion, vvhich vvas meant a Shield:
Then paint the Victors by the Generals skill
Leading their Foes as Captives to their Will:
Discribe the famous Newport, vvhere Alone
He excell'd other Armies and His ovvn;
Here, vvhen the Souldiers Stars like fell avvay,
He solely like the Sun, order'd the Day
Make Him the Governour too of Brill, where He
Single did shevv vvhole Councles Policy,
Although some thought (and The P. of orange & others that perswaded him not adventure on the service, as being impregnable. such too vvho had far
Search'd into th' subtle Stratagems of War)
The Sluce invincible; yet here at length
It must be yeelded to His Persons strength,
And then discribe vvhat Trust, vvhat Fame and State
His ovvn Arme purchas'd in th' Palatinate.
How if Mart-Grave of Ansburgh had obey'd
The subtle and sure Rules His Providence lay'd
The present Austrean Forces then alone
Had not been vanquish'd, but the Region
And the Palatinate had safely stood
Flovving in Milk and Hony, not in Bloud.
Then make From Opulum to Manbaim: Tvvo Armies each in th' others sight
And shevv hovv His Retreat though in the night
Was not a blind Designe, but prov'd to be
The light vvhich sav'd them from their Eenemy;
Though He vvas here of all supplies bereft,
Yet to return He still had spirit left,
And as an Oake, made bare by Winters cold,
Hath still its strength so vvhen forlorne He's bold.
Then tell Vs hovv the States humbly' obey
His Councels, and by Them did others svvay:
How the Maurlet the last that died. Great Prince of Orange did esteeme
His Head beyond the Richest Diademe
These done to the Life, the Figure will appeare
Presenting None but honourable VEERE.
In vvhose brave Frame (for which 'tvvas chiefly built)
The noble Genious of All Souldiers dvvelt,
His shade thus dravvn vvould conquer, vve should see
His Image sent against the Enemy.
And yet hovv poore vvill these Perfections prove?
Here vve might vievv his Power, but nor his Love,
His Vertues still lye hid, here no One sees
His forvvardnesse to teach War-Mysteries,
How He by Precept and Example too,
Would shevv the meanest Souldier vvhere to go,
He not on's Foes alone, but on's Sins trod,
His Prayers vvith Holy Violence conquer'd God
Though He vvith Rabels of Religious meet,
Yet alvvays He escap'd the Tempters Net,
Keeping His Soule untainted, and so came
Home like the God He vvorship'd, STILL THE SAME
I'one hand His Prayer-Book, th'other held His Svvord,
O hovv in Him all vertues did accord!
But Painters cease, here dravv your largest Vayle,
Busie your Thoughts, for novv your hand must fayle,
VEERE's more Heroique Parts do far out-vy

l.hi: The rare effects of Arts bold Industry.

div.head: To the memory of that most Noble Warriour Sir HORATIO VEERE, Baron of Tylbury, &c.

lg.l: GReat Conqueror of Thy selfe, and Men, vve dare
In Govvnes be valiant too, relating VEERE:
And take that Priviledge to vvrong Thy might
By praysing it in Verse, yet thinke 'tis right
Though thus t' abuse the dead 'tvvill prove no vice,
Or beare the Name of pious Covvardise,
We sentence not Thy Worth to th'narrovv Grave,
Or Story forth Thy name i'th' Epitaph.
The Stone may Book thee Captaine of a Shire
That never mustred Troops, but in's ovvn Spheare:
Whose Warlik looks put on vvith rich Array
His scarlet Hose, not vvorne since th' Wedding day,
Did gravely lead the Traine, reviv'd to heare
Defensive Armes and Company so neare:
Whose martiall Termes vvell con'd your Rank and File
For good Artillery pass'd and vvarr'd a vvhile;
Who nere marcht pale but in a Count fight,
And made no use o'th' day, yet look't for night:
Thyne vvere Outlandish fights, although ev'n there
Thy Native passions most oth' Captives vvere,
Grave reason svvay'd the body, and the field,
'Tvvas but the Iudgements taske to make both yeeld
The Tovvns Thou though • 'st to vvyn, vvere novv e'recome,
And in Thy Name, not Armes, they felt their doome:
Eoes vvere as Strangers, only till the Field
Whose chiefest slavery vvas to grant, they yeeld,
No Corps compos'd thy bridge, or marching ground,
'Tvvas not to Conquer this, but tread 'em dovvn.
Thy Wars vvere equall Games, the Lavv and right,
Claym'd greatest part of spoyles l'th' Lord VEERE's sight;
When hottest fields vvere pitcht, and most Men slaine
'Tvvas not to Pyrate Tovvns, but vvinn againe.
Devotion still vvas partner vvith the blovv,
Thou didst at once preach Iustice and o'rethrovv.
Thou vvent'st not o're to spoile some forraigne State,
O'r stead of getting Wit, to propagate.
No vices learnt vvith 'Tongues, no Synne of Note
Inducted vvas vvith this or that Buffe Coate.
'Tvvas not Thy ayme 'Outlandish Realmes to see,
And once return'd, faile in Geography:
To Conne the Map at vvhome, and point the Tovvn
Where you in th' hottest fight lay under ground,
Thy Voyage vvas to fight, not passe the Seas,
Thy Countrey not displeas'd Thee, but its Peace,
Thou vvent's to lend Thy vvounds, and purchase Stars
In forraigne Causes, and in borrovved Wars:
Thou like the Shields from Heaven falne, no end,
No Countrey knevv, but only to defend.

div.head: On the death of the right Honorable the Lord VEERE, Baron of Tilbury. &c.

lg.l: VVHen VEERE deceases, Let none dare to call
His publique Vrne one single funerall.
When so much Valour under Marble lyes,
'Tis not one Man, but a vvhole Troope that dyes:
W'have lost an Army here; the crovvded stone,
At such a fall shuts up a Nation.
This lazy Epitaph some Tombe may vveare,
That the dull Ashes of one Lord lyes here:
Whilst some perhaps thus brand the milde decease,
The quiet Man vvent full of Yeares and Peace:
Yet Thou e're strook vvith Thy ovvn overthrovv,
Who measured'st out a ruine to the Foe:
Thou vvho in War vvert thought Death's Magistrate,
As if alone Thou might'st dispence all Fate,
Who cut those threads off, vvhich vvere Clotho's strife
To dravv into a larger vveb of Life
Who Atropos not ready, nor her Sheares,
Did'st vvith Thy svvord unravell future Yeares;
Be this the honor of Thy Epitaph,
To have Thy Victoreis writ o're Thy Grave,
And vvould Thy Conquests sound! vvhich to rehearse
Would act an other Conquest on All Verse;
No Poetry vvould ever rise so far,
As the plaine Comments of Thy fatall War,
Let others strive for doubtfull Mastery,
And after triall dearer Victors be,
Thou still into the openest field did'st come;
Not to encounter, but fulfill a Doome,
Thus Thy approach still judg'd the Enemy
Who vvas not vanquisht, but condemn'd to dye:
Thy presence startled danger; Then all vvere,
All but the Enemies selfe, secur'd from feare.
Novv this exalts our thoughts, vve feele a flame
Spring in our Veines, as lighted from thy Name
Thus rais'd vve do even vvish an Enemy,
He's almost Souldier that but vvrites of Thee.
Novv I behold Thy forvvard spirit fly
With halfe a vving to dare the Enemy,
Thou scornd'st an equall figure, nor dist ere,
Esteeme of Number as Presage in War.
Yet conquered'st so, as if Thy Men still lay
In ambush clos'd and unseen, got the day
Or as like Cadmus race from out the ground
Grevv into Armour, borne t'inflict a vvound
But that a forraigne Blood, They only shed
And fought not till they left themselves all dead;
So that the greatfull Enemy vvould svvare,
This lessen'd all His Troupes to looke on VEERE
When He summ'd o're His men, it did appeare,
He reckon'd heads, and thou the Souldier.
Novv I behold Thee lead an Army, tyr'd
In a long March, only by Thee inspir'd
Still to renevv the War, and grapple so,
As if they should refresh them on the Fo,
Hovv they their load of Armour all unbrace,
And vvith a nakednesse defend the Place:
Stifled vvith vveight and svveat, hovv they lay by
Their aids, and do themselves get Victory.
Thus vvith thy spirit arm'd they nothing feare,
Vnlesse a Truce, the sad delay of war.
So vvere Thou verst in Horrors and through All
At length arriv'dst to a slovv Funerall
Thou even in dangers did'st grovv old, as if
Ruine and slaughter did preserve Thy Life.
Thus Salamanders live in flames, vvhilst you
Lay on more Pile, Y'increase their vigour too;
Whilst thus to others You prepare an Vrne,
You give a life heere if You let them burne.
Whose Actions all seem'd above Nature Thou
At Thy decrease, art grovvn a wonder too;
For if an ancient Marriner vve style,
Only a long liv'd aged Miracle,
May not a Reverend Hoary Leader passe
For a gray wonder, such as our VEERE vvas,
Since in more desperate stubborne vvaves ev'n He
Svvam oft through Bloud, vvorse than the Marriner Sea,
Thus free 'mongst dangers spite of Enemies Fate,
To All but our desires. Thou did'st dye late,
Had'st Thou surviv'd a vvhile, vve All should svveare
Poets mistooke their other God of W •… .
But vvearied novv of life since Thou did'st knovv
It vvas a prize too great for any Foe;
Such as no dart could ravish from Thee, till
Thou did'st Thy selfe Command the Dart to kill,
Then Thou retyrd'st from War, Thy other Home
And left'st the Campe only to gaine a Tombe:
To act vvhose Ease vvould prove our Victory
Courage nere ovvn'd a Genius but Thee:

div.p: There hath been (of late) such crowding to the Presse, that in the sweat its now in: some letters (happily) have made a faint Impression: But for other faults they are generally Accents, and you may help them in the sound: the reall mistakes are these.
Page 10. line 1 • . read gave. l. 15, r. our Army. p. 28, l. 5 r. reeking. p. 36. l. 7. r. lasts. p. 58. l. 6. r. conveyes. p. 63. l. 4. r. proportion'd. p. 72. l. 7. r. Hovv for And.
